awd_titl_txt: Evolving contributions of the origin recognition complex (ORC) to subtelomeric chromatin
awd_abstract_narration:
Gene duplication is a driving force in molecular evolution, as it provides new genetic material that can be adapted to serve different purposes in living organisms. This project is aimed at elucidating how duplicate genes diverge and their encoded proteins acquire distinct properties. In particular, the research will examine how a protein motif originally capable of one function can be adapted to perform other functions in the cell. The project is also designed to integrate research with training of undergraduate and graduate students who will gain hands-on experience in designing, executing, and interpreting experiments. In addition, a postdoctoral fellow who is planning a career in undergraduate education will gain teaching experience by coaching undergraduates in the laboratory, developing and implementing assessments for an undergraduate laboratory course, and designing and teaching a course during the three-week winter session. Finally, this project will enhance genetic resources for model organisms by developing additional yeast species for comparative evolutionary studies.

The fates of duplicate genes are well-modeled theoretically. However, few studies of gene duplication move beyond sequence analysis to elucidate the changes that occur in protein function as duplicated genes diverge. The project will help fill this knowledge gap by tracing the evolution of two proteins that arose from subunits of the origin recognition complex (ORC). ORC promotes the assembly of a pre-replication complex for DNA synthesis, and five of its six subunits contain AAA+ domains that bind and hydrolyze ATP. In the budding yeast lineage, Orc1 duplicated to yield the heterochromatin protein Sir3, and Orc4 gave rise to the telomere-binding protein Rif2. Both Sir3 and Rif2 lack ATPase activity and have repurposed the AAA+ domain to bind other proteins. The research will compare the molecular properties of Orc1/Sir3 and Orc4/Rif2 in non-duplicated and duplicated yeast species, focusing on their protein interactions and genomic distributions. In addition, the contributions of these proteins to transcriptional repression and telomere length regulation will be examined. The findings will illustrate and clarify theoretical models of gene duplication by identifying how and when new protein functions arise.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project investigated how the properties of proteins shift over time. The importance of this process has recently been brought to public attention, as it has emerged that different versions of the SARS-CoV2 spike protein have varying abilities to enter cells and evade the immune system. To learn about how proteins change, we focused on two proteins, called Orc1 and Orc4, that each gave rise to new proteins through duplication. We found that these proteins first acquired multiple jobs within a cell. Next, the genes encoding these proteins were doubled, and the two copies started accumulating different sequence changes. As time went on, the diverging genes produced different versions of the proteins, such that one version carried out one of the original jobs and the other version carried out the other jobs. This process appears to be a typical one through which new proteins emerge.

The proteins we studied, Orc1 and Orc4, are found in all eukaryotes (organisms that enclose DNA in a nucleus). They assemble with several other proteins to form the Origin Recognition Complex (ORC), which marks the spots in the genome where the copying of DNA starts. Because DNA must be copied each time a cell divides, ORC is essential for cellular life. In yeasts (unicellular fungi), both Orc1 and Orc4 gave rise to new proteins through duplication. The duplicate of Orc1 is Sir3, a protein that “silences” genes, i.e. prevents them from being read to produce proteins. The duplicate of Orc4 is Rif2, a protein that regulates the length of telomeres, the repeated sequence at the end of chromosomes. To understand how these proteins gained new jobs, we compared the duplicated proteins in the lab yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, with their relatives from yeast species that did not undergo the duplication. We made the following discoveries:

  • We confirmed that Orc1 acquired the additional job of gene silencing before it was duplicated. However, of the two ways that Orc1 could act in gene silencing, we only observed one in the non-duplicated yeast species we studied (Torulaspora delbrueckii). This finding helped us order the steps by which Orc1 changed into Sir3. (Maria and Rusche, in preparation)  
  • We identified a portion of Sir3 where new properties evolved after Sir3 diverged from Orc1. In Orc1, this portion of the protein, the AAA+ base subdomain, is intimately associated with other ORC subunits and is required for DNA copying. Consequently, it is constrained to retain its DNA copying function. However, once Sir3 arose and was no longer constrained to assemble into the ORC complex, this portion of the protein evolved to function better in gene silencing.  (Hanner and Rusche, Genetics, 2017)
  • We narrowed down the time at which Sir3 acquired new properties to shortly after the duplication that gave rise to separate SIR3 and ORC1 genes. This timing suggests that once Sir3 was freed from the constraint of serving in DNA copying, it was possible and advantageous for the protein to become better at the Sir3 job of gene silencing. (Zhou, Rusche, et al., in preparation)
  • We found that Orc4 acquired the additional job of regulating telomere length before its gene was duplicated. After duplication, the jobs of DNA copying and telomere regulation were partitioned between the two copies. (Kapoor, Rusche, et al., in preparation)
  • We identified the locations where DNA copying starts in the yeast T. delbrueckii, which did not undergo the duplication of the ORC genes. We found that virtually the same DNA sequence occurs at start sites in T. delbrueckii and its distant cousin, the lab yeast S. cerevisiae. This finding indicates that the start sequence has been maintained for over 100 million years. (Maria and Rusche, Genome Biology & Evolution, 2021)

Broader Impacts: This project provided training for two PhD students, two MS students, and several undergraduates, including a student who had summer research support. In addition, a postdoctoral researcher gained teaching skills by supervising undergraduates in the lab and developing a mini-course that she taught twice over winter session. She went on to a teaching position at Niagara Community College.
